item.title: Beta release
item.description: I didn't make a post yesterday, but I won't count that as missing a day because I actually did a lot of work yesterday. As of today, my game is gameplay complete. It's still missing sound, and I want to fix a few UI problems and other bugs. But I consider those minor changes. There won't be any dramatic changes in the game from here. Check it out here.

item.title: Improved fonts
item.description: Check out my better font rendering! So it turns out I was just being stupid about my fonts. All my complaints were all easily addressed, I was just too lazy to look, since I wanted to get it done quick.

item.title: First alpha
item.description:
Here's my first version of the game! It's only been tested on Chrome and Firefox. Any other browser is on their own. Input doesn't work on mobile phones either.

There's still a bunch of bugs in this release, and I couldn't get text rendering working either, so I'm printing it to the console output. As I've said before, I want to replace my font code anyways.

I want to give a shoutout to John Sharp's blog. Emscripten has a lot of documentation, but for some reason, I could not find the basic usage instructions. And this guy has it all neatly compiled together on his blog.

item.description:
Here's a gif of one of the higher levels. Random sizes and spiky dots.

There's a glitch in this image. A red dot trespasses through the explosion fine without any repercussion. It seems to happen only with large explosions, so it's probably a glitch with my quadtree.

item.title: Invincible spikes
item.description:
I introduced invincible spikes today. Spikes means a dot is invincible, while a gray outline means that a dot can turn invincible.

The player dot uses the same spikes and outline to denote when the player is attacking and when the player is ready to attack.

I made invincible dots to introduce a different type of difficulty in later levels. That's right, my game will have levels. Levels is my last "necessary" feature before I am willing to say my game is in a finished state.

Here are my remaining required tasks:

  • Levels
  • Compile to Windows 10

Here are my remaining optional tasks:

  • Sound
  • Purple dot
  • Saving high scores
  • Power up pick up
  • Better font rendering
  • Hard mode
  • Compile to OS X

Here are tasks I've given up on finishing:

  • Use OpenGL directly
  • Animation
  • Music

The reason I put "levels" above something like "sound" is because my game is honestly quite boring without it. It might have been the primary reason my game was fun. I'll go into more detail when I actually make the levels.

item.title: SDL blending modes
item.description:
So SDL only offers four blending modes: no blending, alpha blending, additive blending, and multiplicative blending. They don't have subtraction or division. Take a look at their alpha blending formula on their documentation. In case their documentation changes in the future, I'll spell it out here.

dstRGB = (srcRGB * srcA) + (dstRGB * (1-srcA))
dstA = srcA + (dstA * (1-srcA))

Note that this blending is not transitive, and the order you render transparent objects matter. I've been using unordered arrays in my code for O(1) deletes. This causes my objects to render in a different order when something is removed from the array.

You can see the rendering errors happen most visibly in the upper left. To get around this, I use additive blending for my explosions. Any color added to white (the background color) is still white, so before rendering the color of every explosion, I render a black circle. The results look quite interesting. This is the only solution I can think of without calling OpenGL, which I don't think I can do if I want to finish this game by next week.

I need to clean up the textures a bit, but I think this looks better.
